title: [FR] support pyspark.ml.autolog read log_model_allowlist file from storage

labels.name: area/tracking
labels.description: Tracking service, tracking client APIs, autologging

body:
### Willingness to contribute

Yes. I would be willing to contribute this feature with guidance from the MLflow community.

### Proposal Summary

Update pyspark.ml.autolog's behavior to accept log_model_allowlist file that's stored in storage like S3 or Azure blob storage. 

### Motivation

#### What is the use case for this feature?
Let pyspark.ml.autolog accept log_model_allowlist file from most storage including S3, Azure blob storage, etc.

#### Why is this use case valuable to support for MLflow users in general?
Take databricks for example, we need to set cluster spark configuration of `spark.mlflow.pysparkml.autolog.logModelAllowlistFile` to point to the file, and if we support reading from whatever storage then this config can accept link to files stored outside of dbfs.

#### Why is this use case valuable to support for your project(s) or organization?
Make the updating log_model_allowlist file process easier, and for specific libraries we can provide a default link that users could point to without downloading & uploading themselves.

#### Why is it currently difficult to achieve this use case?
Currently pyspark.ml.autolog is reading log_model_allowlist file using python's `open` function, which only supports reading files from local disk. This behavior makes updating log_model_allowlist file a bit complicated. 

### Details

1. Within the source code we're reading the file using python's built-in `open` method to read the log_model_allowlist file, one option would be that we replace this `open` with `smart_open.open()`. This `smart_open` library supports reading files from lots of storages (https://github.com/RaRe-Technologies/smart_open) But this need mlflow to depend on smart_open library.
2. We check the format of the config link, and it should be a public-accessible link that we don't need extra confidential to download, then if it's a downloadable link we can download the file and read it.
